   HyperNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=32323338; y=849dY4wyVqz0jsfa-ZC_mYzUAfCTP5vaHeTYvp7VBzrcO9JHNg

Stephen Waits wrote:
> 
> Good news.. it seems to run on my machine at work.

After having run it for almost four hours.. a few random thoughts.  I'm 
sure you've thought about these things much more than me, especially 
since these aren't much more than 2 second impulses through my tiny brain :)

* As Ken says, objective function is going to be important, but I think 
it may not be the *most* important step toward success.

* I wondered about the ability of your body configuration to actually 
stand up?  In that sense, are segment masses appropriate?  Joint limits? 
  Joint accelerations?  Can the muscular forces react quickly and 
forcefully enough?  For example, I can recover from leaning/falling 
forward with a single leg (i.e. a "lunge").  I can furthermore support 
my entire body weight with a single leg.

* I believe we humans have an AWFUL LOT of feedback.  Is it ten times as 
much feedback as it actually is muscle command paths?  Something like 
that.  Anyway, seems that this task is very heavily dependent on lots of 
good feedback.  As an example, I'm seeing quite a bit of this: a) find a 
position that is nearly balanced, b) hold it, c) fall over.  What's your 
feedback look like right now?

* I'm also seeing quite a bit of the weird "squatting toe-stand" 
position, for lack of a better description.  This brings to mind the 
idea of pain.  It hurts me to stand on my toes.  More feedback.

* The problem of balance is incredibly complex (like I need to mention 
this, right?).  There's a certain level of granularity that are probably 
beyond simulation.  For example, we use our toes quite a bit when 
standing ourselves upright.  In some ways, this extra complexity may be 
necessary to efficiently stand; however, in bigger ways (as Ken eludes 
to), they only complicate the search space.

* One fitness related idea I had was to reward individuals that use less 
energy.  For example, to balance, I'd move my arms first, because it's 
easier, than moving my legs.

* I'd like to see you really use the "Hyper" part of "HyperNEAT".  That 
is, evolve something simple, than increase the substrate density with 
100's or even 1000's of nodes.

Overall, it's a very cool project.  I'm looking forward to your next 
upload and please keep up the great work!!!

--Steve
